The '''1997 [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament]]''' involved 64 schools playing in [[Single-elimination tournament|single-elimination]] play to determine the national champion of men's [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[college basketball]]. It began on March 13, 1997, and ended with the [[1997 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship Game|championship game]] on March 31 in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] at the [[RCA Dome]]. A total of 63 games were played.

The Final Four consisted of [[1996–97 Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball team|Kentucky]], who entered the tournament as the defending national champions, [[1996–97 Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball team|Minnesota]], making their first Final Four appearance, [[1996–97 Arizona Wildcats men's basketball team|Arizona]], making their third Final Four appearance and first since 1994, and [[North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball|North Carolina]], making their thirteenth Final Four appearance and first since 1995.

In the national championship game, Arizona defeated Kentucky in overtime 84–79 to win their first national championship. For the second time in the last three seasons, the defending national champions reached the final game and lost.

[[Miles Simon]] of [[Arizona Wildcats men's basketball|Arizona]] was named the tournament's [[NCAA Basketball Tournament Most Outstanding Player|Most Outstanding Player]].

Several years later, [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball|Minnesota]] was stripped of its [[Final Four]] appearance following the discovery of NCAA academic rule violations. In addition, the Gophers were stripped of their [[Big Ten]] title they had also won.<ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/11/21/sports/main251329.shtml</ref>

[[University of Arizona|Arizona]] also became the only school since the introduction of the 64-team bracket in 1985,<ref>http://www.ncaa.com/news/basketball-men/2010-01-28/bracket-question</ref> to defeat three number 1 seeds in the tournament, having upset overall number one seed [[Kansas Jayhawks men's basketball|Kansas]] in addition to their two Final Four victories.

The tournament also saw the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship upsets|third victory by a #15 seed over a #2 seed]], as [[Coppin State University|Coppin State]] defeated [[South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball|South Carolina]] in their first round matchup. In addition, a #14 seed advanced to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Sweet Sixteen]] for only the second time, as Southeast Region #14 seed [[Chattanooga Mocs basketball|Chattanooga]] defeated both [[Georgia Bulldogs men's basketball|Georgia]] and [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball|Illinois]].

The Final Four returned to Indianapolis for the third time, and to the RCA Dome for the second time in seven years. There were three new host cities and four new arenas in the 1997 tournament. For the first time since 1953, the tournament returned to the southern San Francisco Bay area, this time at the San Jose Arena in San Jose. The tournament also saw the first games held at the Alamodome and in San Antonio, the eighth city in Texas to host games; only California has hosted in more cities. The city of Pittsburgh hosted for the first time, at the Civic Arena, the first games played outside Philadelphia within the state of Pennsylvania. Finally, the Palace of Auburn Hills, Detroit's major indoor basketball arena from 1988 to 2017, hosted games for the first time in 1997. All thirteen venues in the tournament have hosted games since this one.
